Proiect Description: The project would support progress toward a sustainable environment for the long term economic and social development of the Colombo Metropolitan Area (CMA). In particular, the project would focus on improving solid waste services, controlling surface- and groundwater contamination from wastewater discharge, and building up the capabilities of the local governments in municipal waste management. The project would also assist in promoting private sector participation in environment-related operations. The project would finance (a) construction of a sanitary landfill and compost facilities to replace open dumps, and equipment for hospital wastes collection, transport and disposal; (b) wastewater collection systems in two industrial zones; (c) wastewater pollution abatement measures in the Beira Lake catchment area; and (d) technical assistance. Project Benefits: The project addresses the underlying causes of environmental degradation in the CMA and will benefit over 3 million people who reside in or commute to the project area. The replacement of open dumps with controlled sanitary landfill will eliminate contamination of surface and ground water from open dump seepage or leachates, improve urban environmental conditions and landscape aesthetics. Improved management of hospital wastes through specialized collection and safe disposal will lower public health impacts of uncontrolled disposal of infectious and pathological wastes. The two industrial areas at Ratmalana and Ekala/Ja-Ela account for about 60% of water-polluting industries in the CMA; the project-supported sewerage investments would therefore lead to a significant reduction in the overall pollution contribution of the industrial sector and a general improvement in the
 population health in the areas concerned. The interventions in the Beira Lake catchment will help reduce associated environmental and health hazards and open the way for environmentally sustainable development of the lake's surrounding area in the longer term. Besides the above direct benefits, the project would serve to catalyze private participation in the delivery of critical urban infrastructure services traditionally undertaken by the public sector. This is expected to contribute to increased service coverage, improved service quality and efficiency. The project would also have a significant demonstration effect to sensitize other urban authorities to adopt better managed and environmentally sound wastes management systems. Prgject Risks: Potential project risks are: (a) shortfalls in cost recovery to sustain the operations of the project supported investments; (b) weak enforcement of industrial wastewater discharge standards, which would reduce pressure on industries to utilize the joint wastewater collection and treatment systems; and (c) lack of adequate response from the private sector for the two wastewater treatment plants. These risks have been recognized and suitable safeguards have been incorporated in the project implementation as detailed below. Cost Recovery. To sustain the operations of project facilities agreement has been reached on the mechanisms for setting up dedicated sources of funds for the above operations and on cost recovery targets satisfactory to IDA. Enforcement. To step up enforcement, GOSL has committed to implementing a time-bound compliance program for the two industrial areas. Under this program, the Central Environmental Authority, NWSDB and each of the targeted industries will enter into an agreement confirming that each industrial entity will comply with established effluent discharge standards through using the proposed joint treatment facilities or its own captive treatment plant. All agreements would be concluded by June 1997. Financing of Wastewater Treatment Plants. To minimize the risk that private sector interest may not materialize in a time frame commensurate with the implementation of the project, GOSL will implement a program of specific actions aimed at concluding contractual agreements with private sponsors by March 1997. International consultants will be mobilized in October 1995 to assist in the preparation of solicitation packages and evaluation of proposals. No withdrawals will be allowed with respect to the wastewater collection works until financing arrangements satisfactory to IDA for the construction of the two wastewater treatment plants have been concluded. In the event that private sector BOO/BOT arrangements fail to develop, GOSL will arrange funds from alternative sources for the construction of the wastewater treatment plants.

 SRI LANKA COLOMBO ENVIRONMENTAL IMPROVEMENT PROJECT STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT I. THE COLOMBO URBAN ENVIRONMENT A. Socioeconomic Setting 1.1 Sri Lanka has a richly varied natural resource base, a moderately expanding population covered by extensive social services and an adult literacy rate of almost 90%. With such an economic infrastructure and human resource base, the Govemment of Sri Lanka (GOSL) is gearing up to propel the economy into the mainstream of growth by fostering private sector-led and environmentally friendly industrial growth, stimulating agriculture to diversify into new crops and export-oriented products, and consolidating Sri Lanka's natural, strategic position by developing the Colombo port into a competitive regional transshipment center. 1.2 The Colombo Metropolitan Area (CMA), which comprises the Colombo Municipal Council (CMC) and 30 othe, local authorities in the Colombo, Kalutara and Gampaha Districts of the Westem Province, is the most developed region in Sri Lanka (see IBRD Map 26954). With over four million inhabitanits, the CMA contains a quarter of Sri Lanka's total population, accounts for above 70% of the country's industrial activities, and generates over 40% of the island's gross domestic product (GDP). This concentration of population, industrial and commercial activities in about 5% of the total land area of Sri Lanka, places a severe strain on the existing municipal infrastructure. Notwithstanding the Govemment's preference for a more balanced regional development, most of the new industrial growth can be expected to be sited in the CMA, which is already bearing the brunt of existing industrial and urban pollution. Recognizing environmental improvement as an essential part of economic development, implementation of adequate environmental management programs to remedy and prevent the adverse effects of urban and industrial growth on the environment in the CMA is on the top of GOSL's environmental agenda. B. Regulatory and Institutional Framework for Environmental Management 1.3 In recent years, GOSL has taken a series of legislative initiatives toward protecting the environment. The National Environmental Act of 1980 establishes a comprehensive national environmental policy. In 1982, GOSL created the Central Environmental Authority (CEA) with policy and regulatory functions. Under the National Environmental (Amendment) Act of 1988, three new instruments were introduced for enhancing environmental protection; these are the requirement of Initial Environmental Examination and Environmental Impact Assessment for approval of projects, the designation of environmental protection areas, and the environmental protection license scheme to enforce industrial effluents discharge standards. The National Environment (Protection and Quality) Regulations of 1990 mainly deals with industrial pollution control.
 -2 - 1.4 The institutional framework for environmental management in Sri Lanka is still evolving. CEA, which functions under the new Ministry of Transport, Highways, Environment and Women's Affairs, is the central agency with a policy and regulatory mandate. The National Environmental Steering Committee (NESC, established in 1990) coordinates and oversees the implementation of all environment-related programs, plans and projects. The members of the NESC include the secretaries/heads of all relevant ministries and agencies. Besides CEA and the NESC, a large number of national agencies are entrusted with specific responsibilities with respect to the various environmental segments, these include, among others, the Coast Conservation Department, the Forest Department, the Department of Wildlife Conservation, the Irrigation Department, the National Water Supply and Drainage Board (NWSDB), and the Urban Development Authority (UDA). The municipal, urban and local govemment admninistrations' are the basic units responsible for ensuring compliance with environmental regulations and standards within their respective jurisdictions. C. Environmental Conditions in Colombo 1.5 The environmental degradation in the CMA derives largely from the poor management of solid and hazardous wastes, and uncontrolled discharge of domestic and industrial wastewater into the area's water courses, which are in tum attributable to the lack of adequate urban infrastructure and effective enforcement of environmental regulations. 1.6 Municipal Solid Waste. According to the existing legislation, the overall responsibility for municipal solid waste collection and disposal rests with each local administration. The solid waste management practices in the various jurisdictions comprising the CMA differ greatly. Regular solid waste collection systems exist in the CMC, Dehiwala-Mt. Lavinia Municipal Council (Dehiwala-Mt. Lavinia MC), Moratuwa Urban Council (Moratuwa UC) and the Kotte Urban Council (Kotte UC); however, in some of the smaller jurisdictions, a solid waste collection system is virtually non-existent. Municipal solid waste in the CMA is presently collected at the rate of about 1I,100 tons per day (tpd), of which about 700 tpd is by the CMC. The ratio of waste collected to waste generated ranges from about 90% in the CMC to as little as 5% in some of the smaller local authorities (LAs). 1.7 Presently, CMC is the only jurisdiction in the CMA that has an organized solid waste management system, with about 1,000 container collection points providing storage of waste prior to collection for disposal. Currently, waste collected in the CMC is deposited at a disposal site at Wellampitiya. During the development of the site, little preparatory work was undertaken to contain surface water, control leachate or prevent gas. Consequently, operation of the site has caused contamination of the local aquifer. Furthermore, the site has already reached its capacity. Thus, CMC is in urgent need of a new sanitary landfill site to avoid the altemative of using open dumps. 1.8 Within the other LAs, waste collection points generally are little more than open patches of ground where waste is dumped, requiring hand-loading onto secondary transport. Current practice of disposing medical waste is not environmentally acceptable. Colombo's 20-odd hospitals generate about 4 tons per day of waste, of which about 3 tons per Jay are clinical wastes. Presently, infectious clinical wastes are deposited together with non-clinical wastes in regular trash containers without special lids to keep them securely fastened. From that point, the containers are transported in open trolleys to an open container il. the hospital where they are kept awaiting pick-up through the CMC's waste collection service. This indiscriminate mixing poses a serious health hazard at each stage of collection and storage within the hospital, and of transport and disposal in landfills and open dumps. 1.10 Wastewater Disposal and Sanitation. The CMC and part of the neighboring Dehiwala- Mt. Lavir. ia MC and ''Colonnawa Urban Council are the only major areas in Sri Lanka with a central sewerage system. Within the sewered area, only about 60% of the population is connected; 25% utilize septic tanks or pit latrines; the remaining 15% has no sanitation facilities at all. Most industries discharge their wastewater without any treatment into surface waters. The CMC sewerage system comprises a network of 265 km of gravity mains, 20 km of force mains and 13 pumping stations. The collected sewerage is discharged without any treatment into the Indian Ocean through two ocean outfalls. The existing sewerage system is not functioning properly due to lack of maintenance, under-capacity and illegal connections. Most of the gravity sewers were built in the early decades of the century and are reportedly subject to periodic collapse. As a result, the discharge and seepage of sewage, industrial wastewater and polluted stormwater cause serious pollution of the surface waters and groundwater in the CMA and of the coastal marine waters. 1.11 Industrial Wastewater Pollution. Colombo and the adjoining areas represent the largest concentration of industrial facilities in Sri Lanka. For nearly two decades industries have been encouraged to grow, without concomitant attention being paid to management of industrial pollution. The resultant industrial wastewater pollution has been especially severe in the Ratmalana/Moratuwa area which has over 225 industrial facilities intermixed with residential and commercial establishments, with a total population of about 350,000. Most of the industries discharge their effluents without any treatment into nearby drainage systems; domestic wastewater from flush toilets is directed to septic tanks and soakage pits. Pressure from the expanding population has forced residents to construct wells adjacent to existing septic tanks, often in violation of minimum safe distances required by planning agencies. The high water table in much of the area further aggravates this problem, and fecal contamination of wells is becoming more evident. Two water bodies, Lunawa Lagoon and Bolgoda Lake are in the area. Because of the continual discharge of wastewater into its tributaries, Lunawa Lagoon, which supported a significant fisheries industry a decade ago, is totally devoid of aquatic life today. Although Bolgoda Lake has not degraded to the sane extent, there is increasing concern that the long term effects of continued industrial wastewater discharge into it will seriously compromise its economic and ecological value. 1.12 Beira Lake. Beira Lake, a distinctive landmark in the center of Colombo and once an economic and aesthetic asset, is now a polluted water body and a public health hazard. The lake has a surface area of 65 hectares (ha.) and is situated in a catchment area of about 448 ha.
 - 4 - Having no natural tributaries of its own, the lake's main source of renewal comes from the runoff waters of its catchment. Its u-shaped configuration gives the lake an exceptionally long shoreline, increasing its susceptibility to runoff from its overall catchment area as well as from inappropriate use of the shoreline. Shoreline uses include industry, warehousing, shipping, marine repair facilities, government offices, hotels, public open space, recreational areas, and religious centers. Nearly 500 low-income housing units with a population of about 2,400 are located along the shore. Large portions of the shoreline have been abused by indiscriminate waste disposal. 1.13 The lake's water quality is very poor, with high concentrations of organic materials and other nutrients, high turbidity and algal growth, wide fluctuations of dissolved oxygen, and high counts of fecal coliform bacteria from domestic sewage. Pollution sources consist principally of stormwater runoff containing illegal discharges of domestic sewage and industrial wastewater, and sewage and solid waste from shanty settlements. Over one thousand stormwater outfalls open into the lake, carrying all forms of urban waste. Raw sewage from overflows in the sewerage network and from unauthorized connections of sewers and septic tanks to storm drains further contaminates the lake. 1.14 To reverse the effects of environmental degradation, restoration of the Beira Lake has been accorded high priority by GOSL. Various studies regarding the water quality of the lake, sources of pollution and options for mitigation have been carried out in recent years. During the preparation of the Colombo Environmental Management Strategy and Action Plan (para. 1.16), a comprehensive study funded by the Canadian Intemational Development Agency (CIDA) was carried out with the objective of formulating a series of practical interventions. The study recommended a 10-year, two-phase restoration strategy. Phase I would focus on reduction of pollutant loadings from the Beira Lake catchment area; Phase I would aim at accelerating the lake's restoration using three in-lake restoration techniques: dredging, filtration of algae, and stocking of algae-eating fish. The proposed project would finance phase I interventions. D. Govemment Strategy 1 .15 National Environmental Action Plan. With the foresight that Sri Lanka has the unique opportunity to pursue economic development in an ecologically sensitive manner, GOSL issued a National Environmental Action Plan (NEAP) in 1991, with the objective to set a framework for the enhancement of sustainable development and to mitigate emerging pollution problems and environmental degradation. The areas of environmental concem addressed under the NEAP include: land and water resources, forestry, biodiversity and wildlife, urban and industrial pollution, energy, and institutional capacity. The NEAP has identified the following priority actions which bear on the environment in the Colombo metropolitan area: * preparation of a wastewater and sanitation master plan and a long-term solid waste management strategy for Greater Colombo, * preparation of a program for the rehabilitation of Colombo's natural drainage system, focusing on restoration of the Beira Lake, and addressing marsh filling and stream and canal reservation settlement;

Stemming from the NEAP, GOSL, with assistance from the Metropolitan Environmental Improvement Program (MEIP), formulated a comprehensive environmental management strategy (EMS) for Greater Colombo. Drawing extensively upon a wide range of excellent documentation available on Sri Lanka's environment, the Colombo EMS documented major environmental problems and their underlying causes, assessed Sri Lanka's environmental policies and institutional capabilities for addressing them, recommended areas for improvement, and proposed a 10 -year program of specific environmental interventions. The proposed project is based upon the prioritized remedial actions proposed in the EMS. 1 17 Current Constraints. While the existing legislation covers the entire range of environmental concems, there is still a large lack of adequate implementation and enforcement. Apart from the shortage of funds for investment in urban infrastructure, the lack of institutional capabilities at the CEA to enforce the existing regulations and standards, and insufficient attention on the part of local govemments to adopting adequate cost recovery measures are constraints to implementation of environmental management programs. To help address the above constraints, the proposed project would assist CMC and other local authorities to operationalize sound solid waste management systems and seek private sector participation under concession agreements. The project would also provide technical assistance to strengthen UDA's capability in integrated urban planning, with a particular focus on environmental planning and management. Institution building technical assistance to CEA would be provided in the proposed Sri Lanka Environmental Action 1 Project which is under preparation. E. Rationale for IDA Involvement 1.18 The proposed operation is consistent with IDA's Country Assistance Strategy for Sri Lanka. The strategy discussed by the Board on December 10, 1992 seeks and supports reforms by GOSL to (a) improve the climate for private initiatives and for export growth and diversification; (b) improve public sector management of human and physical resources with a view to preserving the country's outstanding social achievements and encouraging private sector participation; and (c) strengthen public finances through containment of current expenditures and a more rapid divestiture of Govemment holdings in public enterprises. The strategy also supports programs that contribute to improved environmental management and long-term sustainable economic development, particularly through lending support in urban infrastructure. The proposed project responds to GOSL's priority for addressing emerging environmental problems related to the concentration of economic activity in and around Colombo. The project complements and reinforces the Bank group operations such as the Colombo Urban Transport Project (Cr. 2495-CE) and the proposed Sri Lanka Environmental Action I Project in their institutional support for key agencies involved in environmental protection activities. The project would also support GOSL's effort to seek private

IDA is well-placed to provide assistance because of its involvement in the formulation of the NEAP and Colombo EMS and its ability to catalyze, through policy dialogue with the Government and project financing, the implementation of interventions needed to improve waste management and safeguard the environment. II. THE PROJECT A. Project Objectives 2.1 The overall objective of the project is to contribute to a sustainable environment for the long term economic and social development of the CMA. Specific objectives of the project are to: (a) improve municipal solid waste management and services in the CMC and participating local authorities; (b) reduce wastewater pollution in the Beira Lake catchment area and selected industrialized zones; (c) develop the capabilities of local governments and institutions to plan and manage municipal services in a sustainable, environmentally beneficial manner; and (d) assist in mobilizing private participation in the development and operation of urban infrastructure services. B. Project Descrdtion 2.2 The project would comprise the following components: (a) Municipal Solid Waste Management (US$15.7 million) for: (i) construction of a sanitary landfill of 3.5 million cubic meters capacity at Welisara to meet the disposal needs of CMC and 14 local authorities located in the CMA; (ii) construction of a 100 tons/day capacity compost plant at the Welisara landfill; (iii) provision of potable water supply and other infrastructure for the community residing adjacent to the landfill site; and (iv) purchase of equipment and vehicles for safe collection, transport and final disposal of hospital wastes at the Welisara landfill.

Environmental Aspects 2.4 The project will have a significant positive impact on the environmental quality of the Colombo metropolitan area. Project subcomponents are designed to upgrade the deteriorated environmental conditions caused by deficient or non-existent collection and disposal systems for municipal wastes, especially in relation to water pollution, public health and landscape aesthetics. 2.5 Because the project involves construction of a major sanitary landfill, it is a category A project under IDA's Operational Directive for environmental screening. As part of the project preparation, a full environmental impact assessment (EIA) of the proposed sanitary landfill was prepared by intemational consultants on behalf of the Borrower in accordance with IDA's guidelines. Annex 5 provides the summary of the EIA report. 2.6 The landfill site at Welisara was chosen from a shortlist of six sites after detailed evaluation. Located approximately 10 km north of central Colombo, the landfill site covers approximately 50 hectares and is essentially flat with its elevation at sea level. The area is not suitable for cropping because of salinity and does not contain flora and fauna of ecological significance. More than 90% of the required land is owned by GOSL; population displacement by the landfill is minimal, involving only one family who has accepted the compensation package for resettlement. Potential significant negative environmental impacts pertain to: (a) surface/ground water contamination which may be caused by improper handling of waste construction materials during construction of the landfill site or escape of leachate during operation; and (b) changes to the flood storage capacity of the catchment of the Kalu Oya river, which may lead to increased flooding upstream and downstream of the landfill site. The EIA fully addresses these potential impacts and recommends appropriate mitigation measures. The design of the landfill will incorporate a range of environmental protection measures to ensure that development and operation of the landfill site does not result in unacceptable residual impact on the surrounding environment. These include engineering of containment of the site, provision of a leachate collection and treatment system, bunding and provision of piped potable water supplies to the local community. Taking into account the lack of local expertise in modem sanitary landfills, construction and operation of the landfill and compost plant would be

The combined results of demographic, economic and industrial growth have evolved to a state where generation of municipal and industrial waste is outstripping the capacity of the Govemment of Sri Lanka (GOSL) to provide infrastructure to accommodate ever increasing volumes. The proposed project component would concentrate on CMA's most pressing needs by providing for a new sanitary landfill to replace existing open dumps, assisting in the preparation of a detailed long term waste management strategy and disposal plan for the whole of the metropolitan area, separating hospital waste from municipal waste and devising a program to handle it safely, helping reduce the quantity of waste that requires disposal through the promotion of composting, and finally, by furnishing technical assistance to develop in-country waste management capabilities with particular focus on helping arrange private sector participation in solid waste management. Background. 2. The CMA comprises the Colombo Municipal Council (CMC) and 30 urban local authorities (ULAs) in the Colombo, Kalutara and Gampaha Districts of the Western Province. Up to four million residents plus commuters generate CMA's solid waste. The waste consists mainly of three types: (a) municipal waste from domestic and commercial sources; (b) industrial waste generated within specific industrial parks and by other industries scattered throughout CMA; and (c) hospital waste. As Sri Lanka's industrial and commercial capital, Colombo is expected to grow by one-third over the next decade, thus virtually guaranteeing that waste generation will also continue to grow. 3. Municipal Waste. Studies completed by the National Building Research Organization (NBRO) show that municipal solid waste in CMA is presently collected at the rate of approximately 1,100 tons/day (tpd). The breakdowns are: 680 tpd from CMC, 90 tpd from Dehiwala - Mt. Lavinia, 120 tpd from Moratuwa, and 112 tpd from Kotte, and the rest from the remaining 27 ULAs. The ratio of waste collected to waste generated ranges from approximately 93% in CMC to as little as 5% in some of the smaller ULAs. The current volume of waste to be disposed of annually is 450,000 m3, projected to increase at 4% per annum for the foreseeable future. 4. Hospital Waste. Current disposal of medical wastes is not environmentally acceptable. Dangerous infectious clinical wastes are mixed with municipal waste. This indiscriminate mixing poses a serious health hazard at each stage of collection and storage within the hospital, and of transport and disposal in landfills and open dumps. doc.abstracts: The overall objective of the Colombo Environmental Improvement Project is to contribute to a sustainable environment for the long term economic and social development of the Colombo Metropolitan Area (CMA). Specifically objectives are as follows: 1) improve muncipal solid waste management and services in the Colombo Municipal Council (CMC) and participating local authorities; 2) reduce wastewater pollution in the Beira Lake catchment area and selected industrial zones; 3) develop the capabilities of local governments and institutions to plan and manage municipal services in a sustainable, environmentally beneficial manner; and 4) assist in mobilizing private participation in the development and operation of urban infrastructure services. The project comprises four major components. The first is a municipal solid waste management component which will support the construction of a sanitary landfill, construction of a 100 tons/day capacity compost plant the Welisara landfill, provision of potable water supply and other infrastructure for the communtiy residing adjacent to the landfill site and the purchase of equipment and vehicles for safe collection, transport and final disposal of hospital wastes at the Welisara landfill. The second component supports a wastewater collection system for construction of a sewer network in each of the two industrialized zones, Ratmalana and Ekala/Ja-Ela, to collect and carry industrial and domestic wastewaters to two separate wastewater treatment plants built by the private sector. The third component supports a pollution control program in the Beira Lake catchment for the interception of unauthorized wastewater outlets now discharging to the storm drainage system and connecting them to existing sewerage system and reduction of sewerage overflows through cleaning sewer lines, rehabilitating pumping station, and adding a sewer line along the northwest bank of the East Lake. The final component is a technical assistance component consisting of project preparation assistance, project implementation support, technical assistance to the CMC and technical assistance to the Urban Development Authority.
